contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean basically same thing. The word "house" is a metonym that represents the descendants of Israel. But, both "people" and "house" probably are a synecdoche representing the soldiers of Israel. Alternate translation: "for the Israelite soldiers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: for the people of Yahweh, and for the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated as part of the poetry of the song. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not tell it in Gath ... do not proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated as part of the poetry of the song. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: so that the daughters of the Philistines may not rejoice ... so that the daughters of the uncircumcised may not celebrate

contextId.occurrenceNote: Saul and Jonathan are shown here to have been fierce and valiant warriors. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: From the blood of those who have been killed, from the bodies of the mighty, the bow of Jonathan did not turn back, and the sword of Saul did not return empty

contextId.occurrenceNote: "who provided you nice clothes and jewelry." These two phrases share similar meanings that describe providing the women with expensive, attractive clothing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: who clothed you in scarlet as well as jewels, and who put ornaments of gold on your clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences express similar ideas. They can be combined into one sentence. Alternate translation: "You were in no way a criminal in prison" or "You were completely innocent of doing wrong" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Your hands were not bound. Your feet were not shackled

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh had chosen David to be king. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You will shepherd my people Israel, and you will become ruler over Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. They both are polite ways to refer to death and dying. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: When your days are fulfilled and you lie down with your fathers

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences have similar meanings and emphasize that David's dynasty will last forever. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Your house and kingdom will be confirmed forever before you. Your throne will be established forever.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Sheba is emphasizing that he and the tribes of Israel have no relationship with David. Alternate translation: "The inheritance of David and his father's family does not belong to us" or "We are not a part of David and his father's family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: We have no part in David, neither have we any inheritance in the son of Jesse

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences have similar meanings. Alternate translation: "What can I do to remove this sin, so that you may bless the people of Yahweh, who inherit his goodness and promises?" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: What should I do for you? How can I make atonement ... promises?

May everyone exalt God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: May my rock be praised. May God be exalted

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "God of Israel" is the same as the "Rock of Israel." The two phrases say essentially the same thing. David compares God to a rock to emphasize his power to protect his people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The God of Israel spoke, the Rock of Israel ... me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences both say that the king will respect God and do what God wants him to do. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The one who rules righteously over men, who rules in the fear of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing and are combined for emphasis. Alternate translation: "I have sinned terribly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I have sinned, and I have acted perversely
